response.answer_text: The going principle in science is: “That which is asserted without evidence can be rejected without evidence”. Basically, the obligation to prove any assertion immediately falls onto one that makes it. Firstly, I’d like someone to prove to me unambiguously that this specific verse was the literal words of God, but not an invention of some medieval theologian. Of course, that would require one to prove with a properly set up controlled scientific experiment not only that God exists, but this specific God of Qur’an exists. Then one would need to prove via a properly set up controlled scientific experiment that this exact God (and not some other entity) communicated with the Prophet, and that God gave the Prophet these words precisely. Having established the above we can go into analysing the words of that verse on their scientific merit. You don’t get to do this the other way around starting from the verse and then invite science to refute/deny it without having established the proper scientific credibility of the source for the assertion in the first place. Some homework needs to get done before we get to that place of discussing it in a scientific context. If we were to look at the verse in question it makes/implies several important scientific assertions: A. There exists a God; B. That God created the Universe; C. That God created humans; D. There exists a Heaven; E. That God created humans with a purpose in mind; F. A mechanism by which humans may return to God exists; G. That God communicated that purpose to humans. etc. Now, you see there is a hierarchy here. Without having unambiguously proven the assertion A. via a properly set up controlled scientific experiment we can’t even begin to meaningfully discuss the assertion B. It is just pointless/lacks scientific merit without this. That’s because the assertion B is contingent on the assertion A. being (proven) true. Same applies to any downstream assertion above - they lack merit without having proven the upstream ones: you can’t discuss/entertain the assertion E. without having unambiguously proven the assertion C. Simply put, if one can’t properly prove the assertion A. to be true, any downstream assertion from it can be just outright rejected without the need for any further justification/action. That’s the line of thought that science takes in relation to any topic. I mean no disrespect, but Qur’an is a compilation of Middle-Eastern folk lore and oral tradition that was codified several centuries after the death of the Prophet. Meaning, we can’t know for certain what the precise words of the Prophet were and what He meant by them. Or even whether He uttered these words at all to begin with or had they been a later invention by His followers. We can’t go back and ask for clarification and we can’t verify them independently from the Quran. The veracity of the accounts in the Qur’an can’t be established in principle (as with most other Holy Books). So there is nothing for science to study and scrutinise there, maybe apart from the historical/cultural significance of this work. But certainly not from the POV of cosmology or biogenesis the areas that this verse goes into. And we do know the people who were behind the effort of collecting and systematising the folk lore/oral tradition that made Qur’an and their process for doing it. Going around villages recording their folk lore does not meet the definition of scientific discovery in the slightest and can’t amount to evidence of anything. Apart from the fact that this certain folk lore did exist in the region and people went about collecting codifying it. Qur’an seems to contain significant personal input from those who were behind the project of writing it down. Why they used certain words, how they structured the text, what stories they chose to include or not include. That may be an interesting area of study. But trying to reconcile that text with the modern scientific developments, IMHO, is an exercise in futility. Largely because Qur’an was never intended to be a work of science, but rather a work on philosophy.

Shahid Zaidi, my friend, although I try not to be totally ignorant of the Islamic scriptures there is much that I am unfamiliar with. When I read these verses, however, I think I see what you mean.  I write a lot about the problem of time. All of what we call ‘science’ is conducted in time, and the mathematical logic used in parts of scientific reasoning is paradoxically independent of time. In this way, all seconds are the same (in that they are identical units) and the only way of telling one second from another is by periodic motion which (by definition) is repetitive. Therefore, there is indeed a problem with our measurement of time, since humans live in the present and every sense in which we can determine our history depends on recollection of symbols (writing and pictures, for example) which are repetitively re-interpreted in a way that revises their relevance in every instant. Thus, well may God say ‘if only you knew!’. The one thing we cannot have is a coherent sense of time. We must separate past, present and future in a way that makes each of them independent of the others. Of course, doing so is erroneous - yet it is what happens every time we nominate ‘Now’. For this reason, one of my heroes (St Augustine) says similarly: What then is time? If no one asks me, I know what it is. If I wish to explain it to him who asks, I do not know. Truthfully, Science is silent regarding the essential nature of time, since every subject of scientia depends upon it a priori.
